plants.name: Crocus vernus
plants.description: A small perennial flowering plant growing from a bulb, often one of the first signs of spring in temperate climates. It produces goblet-shaped flowers that can be purple, yellow, or white.
plants.bloomingSeason: Late winter to early spring (February to April)
plants.location: Europe and North America (cultivated in gardens)
plants.funFact: Crocuses are among the earliest bloomers and can even push through snow to bloom, signaling the approaching spring.

plants.name: Camellia japonica
plants.description: An evergreen shrub known for its large, showy flowers, often blooming during the winter months and early spring. It has glossy leaves and blooms in shades of red, pink, and white.
plants.location: East Asia (native); widely cultivated in temperate gardens worldwide
plants.funFact: Camellias were highly prized in Japan and China and are symbols of admiration and perfection.

plants.name: Banksia integrifolia
plants.description: A medium-sized tree or shrub with distinctive cylindrical flower spikes that bloom in winter through spring. The flowers provide important nectar for birds and insects.
plants.bloomingSeason: Winter to spring (June to September in Southern Hemisphere, overlapping with February in Northern Hemisphere subtropics)
plants.funFact: Banksias are named after Sir Joseph Banks, the botanist who accompanied Captain Cook on his voyage to Australia.

plants.name: Mahonia aquifolium
plants.description: An evergreen shrub with holly-like leaves and bright yellow flowers that bloom in late winter, followed by dark blue berries.
plants.bloomingSeason: Late winter to early spring (February to April)
plants.funFact: Oregon grape is a common ornamental plant and also used in traditional medicine by Indigenous peoples.
